name: Brazilian Waterweed
description: Elodea densa (synonym: Egeria densa), commonly known as Brazilian Waterweed, Anacharis, or Dense Waterweed, is a fast-growing aquatic plant native to South America, particularly Brazil, Argentina, and Uruguay, though it has been naturalized in many parts of the world. It belongs to the Hydrocharitaceae family and features whorled, lanceolate to oblong, bright green leaves (1-3 cm long, 2-4 mm wide) arranged in groups of 3-6 along branching stems. The leaves are slightly serrated along the edges. This plant displays an upright, bushy growth habit and can reach 60-100 cm in length. This aquatic plant can thrive both fully submerged and partially emersed. In its native wetland or aquatic habitat, this plant grows fully or partially submerged in still or slow-moving water, adapting to fluctuating water levels. It produces small, white, three-petaled flowers that float on the water surface. In terrariums or indoor settings, this plant adds natural beauty, dynamic movement, and excellent water filtration to aquatic environments. It's one of the most popular beginner aquarium plants due to its hardiness and fast growth.
careTips: Extremely hardy and beginner-friendly - tolerates wide range of conditions
Can be planted in substrate or left floating - both methods work well
Very fast growing - excellent for nutrient export and algae prevention
Easy to propagate by cutting stems - simply cut and replant or let float
Provides excellent oxygenation for aquariums - releases oxygen during photosynthesis
Trim regularly to control growth - can become invasive if not managed
Native to South America (Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay) - prefers moderate temperatures (15-28Â°C)
Low to moderate light is sufficient (1-2 watts per gallon) - very adaptable
Prefers pH 6.5-8.0 and soft to hard water (2-20 dGH) - very forgiving
CO2 supplementation beneficial but not required - grows well without it
Non-toxic and safe for all aquarium inhabitants
Can be used as background or midground plant, or as floating cover
If leaves melt when first introduced, new growth will adapt to tank conditions
Watch for overgrowth - can shade other plants if not trimmed regularly
